instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message:
I have two <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> came in today, identical machines with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards.


problems are the same, machine can power on, chime , back light will be on (after it chimes and wait like 20 seconds later). sometimes no back light but still chime.

if it has back light, then that's it, no flashing folder, or apple logo, just black screen with back light ( just like usually we see it boots up but no apple in the middle)

remove SSDs, and tried other screen tops , still same story.this problem is pretty similar to the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with the soldering problem of <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>
( Which Duke figured out and let me say that was absolutely brilliant !! )

so tried to compare that with this board, but pretty much have no clue, maybe not related. anyone seen similar stuffs?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message: Not common. What is the history on this? PRAM reset?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message:
yea already tried PRAM reset.
history of board, customer sent in entire machine, said just happen one day , no liquid spilled, it's a bit dusty as we see here, but can't find liquid spilled

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message:
external shows nothing. I also notice something, when back light is not present, what's missing to boost the circuit is the <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>
which comes from <CHIP>U8330</CHIP>.
then what's missing for <CHIP>U8330</CHIP> to output <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> is <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> (0v? close to) ,which comes from the CPU.....

not sure if Im thinking the right way though

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message: You 100% sure tried a known good LCD?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message: yes sir, I swapped it with another screen top already and still same thing. and if it's just the screen,external should post as well...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is high 3. something so it's good.
one of the customers agreed to replace the whole board by paying extra. replaced one board today and all good,so it's not the display.  and having the other one left now ( had two came in and same issues)
I will try my best if found any cure will report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> video problem.  common problem?
threads.message: I would check the caps and resistors in the eDP lines to the LCD. Damaged connector also possible.
